body: Will this be fixed?

@feng-tao  Ok . I guess i will only ask one question that seem still unclear to me.  In your google docs you mention that admin could create a new role to allow read/write access on a set of dag. Is there a feature that allows you to group dag in a set and then use the group to filter them ? I see that we can set filter all_dag and by dag_id which means we need to select each individual dag an add it to role permissions ?

@feng-tao I believe the API of FAB is still in beta and subject to change in future. Also, most of the DAG's functionality in Airflow is custom written and not actually using the ModelView. That means, you'd need to overwrite most of the base functions of ModelView along with the filters and widgets.

@gauthiermartin currently not. The fab security model doesn't have the concept of 'group', so users are directly mapped to roles. It's possible to create our own abstraction layers later on, but is out of scope for this pr.

Thanks @ashb and @Fokko for the comments. I think the discussion about how to integrate this with existing hooks is an important issue, but it is not quite clear for me how this would best be solved. 

The new SFTP hook implements most functionality of the existing hook, so dropping that hook from contrib would be possible, at the cost of changing the interface. I think this would be acceptable if the changes are integrated into a new major version of Airflow, rather than a new minor version. We can integrate any missing functionality into the new hook.

The existing S3 hook is a bit more difficult, as the new hook represents S3 as a file system, whilst the existing hook stays closer to the notion of S3 as a key-based blob store. As such, methods such as `select_key` and `list_prefixes` have no clear meaning in my proposed S3FsHook, as these aren't file system concepts. We could integrate some of these methods into the S3FsHook, but it would dilute the interface considerably, I fear. 

I think the two options we have are to:

1. Keep two separate hooks, one for S3 as a file system and one for S3 as a blob store.
2. Keep both interfaces, but separate the blob store interface into a sub-property of the hook to keep the interfaces separate. This would still require separating the existing S3Hook from the AwsHook base class, to avoid multiple inheritance (as we would need to inherit from both FsHook and AwsHook otherwise). S3Hook could still use the AwsHook through composition, as the only thing the AwsHook is really needed for is fetching the client and/or credentials. The only other option would be to make FsHook a mixin, but I fear that that would lead to dilution of the interface. 

I would be keen to hear your ideas on this.
This is awesome. looking into it...

I would like to stress that the biggest advantage of having a common interface for file systems is that it becomes easier to write operators/hooks that read/write to different (combinations of) file systems. For example, by combining these file system hooks we can essentially copy files between any of the file systems (by using specific source/destination hooks), rather than being limited to copying from local to/from a specific file system.

but @yrqls21 , regarding to your startup time issue, why not increase numbers of dagbag processes config (``#max_threads`` )from default 2 to a larger value if that's dagbag loading is taking long time if I understand your issue correctly? At lyft, we found that it significantly improves the performance for dagbag loading time. I create an entry before in faq(https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/docs/faq.rst).  And I am curious how do you pinpoint the issue is due to that line causes the startup issue, and how much startup time gets reduced by removing that line at Airbnb.

hey @verdan , I am not aware of BETA for FAB API. But it works pretty well for me. And given airflow api is also experimental, I think they are considered equally readiness.

I am wondering how you use the airflow api stuffs(or how does your deployment looks like)? Are you going to deploy two webservers, one serves UI and another serves api? Consolidate the api into modelView(once FAB becomes default UI) will be better imo. In that case UI, cli, api request could all serve by FAB model CRUD instead of two different places.

@feng-tao I do not understand why does a scheduler config have to do with webserver start up time. [Webserver load dagbag in a single thread fashion](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/www/views.py#L101) as I stated in my previous comment.

You are perfectly correct that increasing # of dag file processor would help speeding up DAG file parsing. Airbnb recently bumped that up from 64 to 128 and observed improvements. However we have some limitations:

- from experimentation, on the AWS EC2 i3.16xlarge host, 256 DAG file processor would cause `Too many open files` errors( while OS limit is millions, not sure about the root cause, suspecting file handler not closed properly) and it can be limited by the computer power of the scheduler host/container.
- scheduler loop speed would be the bottleneck when we have limited # of DAG file processors, especially when we have large # of DAG files--I'll be sending out several PRs over the next quarter to scale up the scheduler.

Definitely not having two versions of the hooks is crucial.

For the case of S3: yes, s3 is not a filesystem. But the "fs"-like interfaces should be implemented as method on the existing S3 hook using the existing methods where possible. i.e. `walk()` would use `list_prefixes()` in someway. Anything else is just going to make long-term maintenance too hard.

Multiple inheritance is entirely possible in python, and having:

```
class S3Hook(FsHook, AwsHook):
```

would be reasonable in this case.
Deleted my old pull req because it had too many commits and it should be easier to understand like this

@feng-tao totally agreed that there should be only one source of truth for all UI, CLI and API. I'll explore the FAB CRUD more, and see if we can convert all of our views to ModelView. 
To answer your question about the usage of airflow apis, I am trying to write REST APIs for all features of Airflow, in an effort to port the frontend (Web UI) in ReactJS (or any other framework, that's still an ongoing discussion), so that our javascript code is more manageable and testable. 
ref: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-2598

In that setup, I see no use of FAB UI and FAB's CRUD, but just to keep the backward compatibility. thoughts?

@verdan I should note that It's very hard to recover credentials from the Connections.
Sometimes we want to pass the credentials  as parameters to a script because the script is already written and we don't want to convert it to Airflow code using the sensor etc.. so we just want to write a bash operator that runs the script. Currently we are unable to get the credentials from the connection settings so we had to hard-codded the connection credentials in the script. This means that if a username has change we have to look in many places rather than chaining it in one place.  From all answers over stack-overflow getting the credentials  from the Connection was available in 1.8 but not in 1.9
